metadata.title: The Flimsy, Dangerous Indictment of James Comey
metadata.author: ByRuth Marcus

content.text: The LedeThe Flimsy, Dangerous Indictment of James ComeyThe charges against the former F.B.I. director look weak. But they may be just the start of Donald Trump’s long-threatened drive to use the Justice Department to go after his enemies.By Ruth MarcusSeptember 26, 2025FacebookXEmailPrintSave StoryPhotograph by Carsten Koall / GettySave this storySave this storySave this storySave this storyThursday’s indictment of the former F.B.I. director James Comey bore a single, telling signature: that of Lindsey Halligan, installed by President Donald Trump just three days earlier to serve as the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. Halligan is an insurance lawyer turned Trump attorney and White House aide; in March, Trump appointed her to remove “improper ideology” from the Smithsonian. She has scant experience in federal courts and none as a prosecutor. Her predecessor in the position, a seasoned prosecutor nominated by Trump, was forced out last Friday, according to numerous news reports, after balking at demands to concoct cases against Comey, in dition to New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, and others.The LedeReporting and commentary on what you need to know today.The next day, Trump dressed a post on his Truth Social platform to Attorney General Pam Bondi: “JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!” Prosecutors in Halligan’s office reportedly submitted a memorandum to Halligan outlining the weakness of the Comey case. None of those concerns mattered, apparently. Trump finally secured the indictment he h long been calling for. At this point, a prudent President would have stayed silent. Not this one. He posted, “JUSTICE IN AMERICA! One of the worst human beings this Country has ever been exposed to is James Comey, the former Corrupt He of the FBI. . . . He has been so b for our Country, for so long, and is now at the beginning of being held responsible for his crimes against our Nation.” The Department of Justice’s own news release contained the usual boilerplate about an indictment being merely an allegation and the presumption of innocence that all defendants enjoy—legal niceties that struck a particularly disingenuous note in light of Trump’s triumphalism. The President went on to suggest that more of his enemies may face charges: “It’s not a list, but I think there will be others,” he said on Friday morning, en route to watch the Ryder Cup.Grand-jury proceedings are well known to favor the prosecutor—a state-court judge famously remarked that “any good prosecutor can get a grand jury to indict a ham sandwich”—but there is not much meat in the Comey indictment. One meagre count alleges false statements to Congress; the other alleges obstruction of a congressional proceeding arising from the same testimony. (Notably, the grand jurors refused to approve a third count, which reportedly pertained to another allegedly false statement.) Both charges stem from Comey’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 30, 2020—specifically, the indictment cites an exchange Comey h with the Republican senator Ted Cruz about whether Comey h authorized leaks to the media about the F.B.I.’s 2016 investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Cruz referenced a 2017 hearing, during which the Republican senator Chuck Grassley asked Comey whether he h “ever been an anonymous source” or “authorized someone else at the F.B.I. to be an anonymous source” in news reports about matters concerning the Trump or Clinton investigations. When Comey denied both, Cruz pressed him about a contrary account provided by his former deputy director, Andrew McCabe.CRUZ: “Now, what Mr. McCabe is saying and what you testified to this committee cannot both be true. One or the other is false. Who’s telling the truth?”COMEY: “I can only speak to my testimony. I stand by the testimony you summarized that I gave in May of 2017.”The indictment alleges that “that statement was false,” because, as Comey “then and there knew, he in fact h authorized PERSON 3 to serve as an anonymous source in news reports regarding an F.B.I. investigation concerning PERSON 1.” This was presumably Hillary Clinton, because the leak at issue related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into Clinton’s e-mails and the Clinton Foundation.That’s it? That’s the crime? It’s hard to imagine that any responsible or ethical prosecutor would bring this case. In order for a false statement to be criminal, it must be me “knowingly and willfully.” Obstruction of Congress requires the defendant to have acted “corruptly.” The evidence that Comey did either appears sorely lacking. According to a 2018 report by the Justice Department’s inspector general, McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to speak with the reporter Devlin Barrett, who was with the Wall Street Journal at the time, about the F.B.I. investigation of the Clinton Foundation in October, 2016. But Comey did not join in that authorization, the inspector general found. Indeed, according to the inspector general, the evidence suggested that, after the article was published, McCabe misled Comey about McCabe’s role in the leak. While the two men remembered their conversation differently, the inspector general found that “the overwhelming weight of that evidence supported Comey’s version of the conversation.” (McCabe disputed the inspector general’s conclusions.)In other words, there’s no evidence that Comey pre-approved the leak of information; the evidence that he blessed such action after the fact is contested at best. Who is Halligan’s chief witness going to be? McCabe, a man whom Trump repeatedly attacked for being biased against him? Among other inconvenient facts, the Justice Department unsuccessfully set out during Trump’s first term to prosecute McCabe over his alleged misstatements to investigators. As Benjamin Wittes and Anna Bower wrote for Lawfare before the Comey indictment was issued, “It would be quite rich, having sought and failed to charge one party to a memory dispute to turn around and try to charge the other.” (It’s unlikely but conceivable that the indictment references a different episode: Comey’s use of the Columbia Law School professor Daniel Richman to funnel information to the New York Times about Trump’s demands, in 2017, that Comey pledge loyalty to him. Prosecutors reportedly interviewed Richman recently, but Richman’s role did not come up during Comey’s Senate testimony.)“My heart is broken for the Department of Justice,” Comey said, in a video posted on Instagram, even as he expressed confidence about the ultimate outcome. One move would be for Comey’s lawyers to try to have the charges thrown out on the grounds of vindictive or selective prosecution, basically arguing that Comey was targeted for impermissible reasons. As it happens, Trump’s criminal lawyers—including the Deputy Attorney General, Todd Blanche—tried this very tactic against the former special counsel Jack Smith, seeking to have charges against Trump dismissed on the basis that President Joe Biden’s “publicly stated objective is to use the criminal justice system to incapacitate President Trump, his main political rival and the leing candidate in the upcoming election.” Their main evidence was a Times report detailing Biden’s frustration with the slow pace of the Trump investigation. The U.S. district judge Tanya Chutkan appropriately rejected this long-shot bid, noting that courts are “properly hesitant to examine” prosecutorial motives and that there was “no indication that President Biden ever expressed any such comments to the Attorney General or the Justice Department, much less that such comments actually resulted in politically motivated action.” The strong aroma of abusive conduct in the Comey case might incline the judge, Michael Nachmanoff, to opt a more skeptical approach to the charges. (Nachmanoff is a former public defender nominated by Biden. Trump, surprising no one, assailed him in a Truth Social post Friday morning as “a Crooked Joe Biden appointed Judge.”)Comey, in his Instagram video, expressed his eagerness to proceed. “Let’s have a trial,” he said. If it comes to that, the indictment’s seeming flimsiness suggests a conviction may be difficult to secure. That offers cold comfort. The danger in Trump’s second term was always that he would deploy the criminal law to punish his enemies. Now that moment has arrived. “Fear is the tool of a tyrant,” Comey said, quoting his daughter Maurene, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was fired in July, apparently solely because her last name is Comey. But tyrants work through enablers, too, and Trump has them in force. It is bone-chilling to see officials sworn to minister justice bend to Trump’s will, in violation of their ethical duties. In January, at Bondi’s confirmation hearing, the Democratic senator Amy Klobuchar sought assurances that Trump would not be permitted to tamper with criminal cases. “I believe that the Justice Department must be independent and must act independently,” Bondi assured her. “Politics will not play a part.” In the moment, her words offered a filament of hope. Today, they stand as an indictment—this one, sly justified—of what the institution has become. ♦

        </script><script type="text/javascript">window.cns = window.cns || {}; window.cns.pageContext = {"channel":"news","content":{"copyCount":1417,"imageCount":0,"embedCount":3,"ratio":472.3333333333333,"midContentCadence":900},"contentType":"article","experiments":{"bucketLabel":[],"experimentLabel":[],"payload":[]},"functionalTags":[],"keywords":{"copilotid":["68d69e4ac4370b59fd930dad"],"platform":["verso"],"tags":["james-comey","donald-trump","department-of-justice","indictments","enemies","news","the-lede","hero-options","background-color-000000"]},"targeting":{"feature_flags":[]},"server":"production","slug":"the-flimsy-dangerous-indictment-of-james-comey","subChannel":"the-lede","subSubChannel":"","templateType":"mt_article"};</script><link href="https://ads-static.conde.digital" rel="preconnect"/><script async="" id="ads-v6" src="https://ads-static.conde.digital/production/cns/builds/the-new-yorker/v6.js"></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"The next day, Trump addressed a post on his Truth Social platform to Attorney General Pam Bondi: “JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!” Prosecutors in Halligan’s office reportedly submitted a memorandum to Halligan outlining the weakness of the Comey case. None of those concerns mattered, apparently. Trump finally secured the indictment he had long been calling for. At this point, a prudent President would have stayed silent. Not this one. He posted, “JUSTICE IN AMERICA! One of the worst human beings this Country has ever been exposed to is James Comey, the former Corrupt Head of the FBI. . . . He has been so bad for our Country, for so long, and is now at the beginning of being held responsible for his crimes against our Nation.” The Department of Justice’s own news release contained the usual boilerplate about an indictment being merely an allegation and the presumption of innocence that all defendants enjoy—legal niceties that struck a particularly disingenuous note in light of Trump’s triumphalism. The President went on to suggest that more of his enemies may face charges: “It’s not a list, but I think there will be others,” he said on Friday morning, en route to watch the Ryder Cup.\nGrand-jury proceedings are well known to favor the prosecutor—a state-court judge famously remarked that “any good prosecutor can get a grand jury to indict a ham sandwich”—but there is not much meat in the Comey indictment. One meagre count alleges false statements to Congress; the other alleges obstruction of a congressional proceeding arising from the same testimony. (Notably, the grand jurors refused to approve a third count, which reportedly pertained to another allegedly false statement.) Both charges stem from Comey’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 30, 2020—specifically, the indictment cites an exchange Comey had with the Republican senator Ted Cruz about whether Comey had authorized leaks to the media about the F.B.I.’s 2016 investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Cruz referenced a 2017 hearing, during which the Republican senator Chuck Grassley asked Comey whether he had “ever been an anonymous source” or “authorized someone else at the F.B.I. to be an anonymous source” in news reports about matters concerning the Trump or Clinton investigations. When Comey denied both, Cruz pressed him about a contrary account provided by his former deputy director, Andrew McCabe.\n\nCRUZ: “Now, what Mr. McCabe is saying and what you testified to this committee cannot both be true. One or the other is false. Who’s telling the truth?”\n\n\nCOMEY: “I can only speak to my testimony. I stand by the testimony you summarized that I gave in May of 2017.”\n\nThe indictment alleges that “that statement was false,” because, as Comey “then and there knew, he in fact had authorized PERSON 3 to serve as an anonymous source in news reports regarding an F.B.I. investigation concerning PERSON 1.” This was presumably Hillary Clinton, because the leak at issue related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into Clinton’s e-mails and the Clinton Foundation.\nThat’s it? That’s the crime? It’s hard to imagine that any responsible or ethical prosecutor would bring this case. In order for a false statement to be criminal, it must be made “knowingly and willfully.” Obstruction of Congress requires the defendant to have acted “corruptly.” The evidence that Comey did either appears sorely lacking. According to a 2018 report by the Justice Department’s inspector general, McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to speak with the reporter Devlin Barrett, who was with the Wall Street Journal at the time, about the F.B.I. investigation of the Clinton Foundation in October, 2016. But Comey did not join in that authorization, the inspector general found. Indeed, according to the inspector general, the evidence suggested that, after the article was published, McCabe misled Comey about McCabe’s role in the leak. While the two men remembered their conversation differently, the inspector general found that “the overwhelming weight of that evidence supported Comey’s version of the conversation.” (McCabe disputed the inspector general’s conclusions.)\nIn other words, there’s no evidence that Comey pre-approved the leak of information; the evidence that he blessed such action after the fact is contested at best. Who is Halligan’s chief witness going to be? McCabe, a man whom Trump repeatedly attacked for being biased against him? Among other inconvenient facts, the Justice Department unsuccessfully set out during Trump’s first term to prosecute McCabe over his alleged misstatements to investigators. As Benjamin Wittes and Anna Bower wrote for Lawfare before the Comey indictment was issued, “It would be quite rich, having sought and failed to charge one party to a memory dispute to turn around and try to charge the other.” (It’s unlikely but conceivable that the indictment references a different episode: Comey’s use of the Columbia Law School professor Daniel Richman to funnel information to the New York Times about Trump’s demands, in 2017, that Comey pledge loyalty to him. Prosecutors reportedly interviewed Richman recently, but Richman’s role did not come up during Comey’s Senate testimony.)\n“My heart is broken for the Department of Justice,” Comey said, in a video posted on Instagram, even as he expressed confidence about the ultimate outcome. One move would be for Comey’s lawyers to try to have the charges thrown out on the grounds of vindictive or selective prosecution, basically arguing that Comey was targeted for impermissible reasons. As it happens, Trump’s criminal lawyers—including the Deputy Attorney General, Todd Blanche—tried this very tactic against the former special counsel Jack Smith, seeking to have charges against Trump dismissed on the basis that President Joe Biden’s “publicly stated objective is to use the criminal justice system to incapacitate President Trump, his main political rival and the leading candidate in the upcoming election.” Their main evidence was a Times report detailing Biden’s frustration with the slow pace of the Trump investigation. The U.S. district judge Tanya Chutkan appropriately rejected this long-shot bid, noting that courts are “properly hesitant to examine” prosecutorial motives and that there was “no indication that President Biden ever expressed any such comments to the Attorney General or the Justice Department, much less that such comments actually resulted in politically motivated action.” The strong aroma of abusive conduct in the Comey case might incline the judge, Michael Nachmanoff, to adopt a more skeptical approach to the charges. (Nachmanoff is a former public defender nominated by Biden. Trump, surprising no one, assailed him in a Truth Social post Friday morning as “a Crooked Joe Biden appointed Judge.”)\nComey, in his Instagram video, expressed his eagerness to proceed. “Let’s have a trial,” he said. If it comes to that, the indictment’s seeming flimsiness suggests a conviction may be difficult to secure. That offers cold comfort. The danger in Trump’s second term was always that he would deploy the criminal law to punish his enemies. Now that moment has arrived. “Fear is the tool of a tyrant,” Comey said, quoting his daughter Maurene, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was fired in July, apparently solely because her last name is Comey. But tyrants work through enablers, too, and Trump has them in force. It is bone-chilling to see officials sworn to administer justice bend to Trump’s will, in violation of their ethical duties. In January, at Bondi’s confirmation hearing, the Democratic senator Amy Klobuchar sought assurances that Trump would not be permitted to tamper with criminal cases. “I believe that the Justice Department must be independent and must act independently,” Bondi assured her. “Politics will not play a part.” In the moment, her words offered a filament of hope. Today, they stand as an indictment—this one, sadly justified—of what the institution has become. ♦","isBasedOn":"","articleSection":"the lede","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Ruth class="ArticlePageChunksContent-enJWmu eAYWRW"><div class="ArticlePageChunks-fwcPjP kOsxGm" data-testid="ArticlePageChunks"><div class="GridWrapper-cFSKbf fubVbh grid grid-margins grid-items-0 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hkPQhP kHJhWe"><div class="GridItem-beYvyV bRelOV grid--item"><div class="BodyWrapper-kzyFNv BAJMj body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading">Thursday’s indictment of the former F.B.I. director <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/james-comeys-intellectual-history">James Comey</a> bore a single, telling signature: that of Lindsey Halligan, installed by President <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/tag/donald-trump">Donald Trump</a> just three days earlier to serve as the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. Halligan is an insurance lawyer turned Trump attorney and White House aide; in March, Trump appointed her to remove “improper ideology” from the Smithsonian. She has scant experience in federal courts and none as a prosecutor. Her predecessor in the position, a seasoned prosecutor nominated by Trump, was <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/the-lede/donald-trumps-firing-of-a-federal-prosecutor-crosses-the-reddest-of-lines">forced out</a> last Friday, according to numerous news reports, after balking at demands to concoct cases against Comey, in addition to New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, and others.</p><div class="GenericCalloutWrapper-IJXIe cGJMAp callout--has-top-border" data-testid="GenericCallout"><aside class="Sidebar-jNJZm fwNHAh" data-testid="SidebarEmbed"><p class="paywall"><strong>The Lede</strong><br/><a href="https://www.newyorker.com/the-lede"><em>Reporting and commentary on what you need to know today.</em></a></p></aside></div><p class="paywall">The next day, Trump addressed a post on his Truth Social platform to Attorney General Pam Bondi: “JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!” Prosecutors in Halligan’s office <a class="external-link" data-event-click='{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/newly-appointed-us-attorney-attempt-charge-james-comey/story?id=125906268"}' data-offer-url="https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/newly-appointed-us-attorney-attempt-charge-james-comey/story?id=125906268" href="https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/newly-appointed-us-attorney-attempt-charge-james-comey/story?id=125906268" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">reportedly</a> submitted a memorandum to Halligan outlining the weakness of the Comey case. None of those concerns mattered, apparently. Trump finally secured the indictment he had long been calling for. At this point, a prudent President would have stayed silent. Not this one. He posted, “JUSTICE IN AMERICA! One of the worst human beings this Country has ever been exposed to is James Comey, the former Corrupt Head of the FBI. . . . He has been so bad for our Country, for so long, and is now at the beginning of being held responsible for his crimes against our Nation.” The Department of Justice’s own news release contained the usual boilerplate about an indictment being merely an allegation and the presumption of innocence that all defendants enjoy—legal niceties that struck a particularly disingenuous note in light of Trump’s triumphalism. The President went on to suggest that more of his enemies may face charges: “It’s not a list, but I think there will be others,” he said on Friday morning, en route to watch the Ryder Cup.</p><div><div aria-hidden="true" class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-jkpAEW hssEkF consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p class="paywall">Grand-jury proceedings are well known to favor the prosecutor—a state-court judge famously remarked that “any good prosecutor can get a grand jury to indict a ham sandwich”—but there is not much meat in the Comey indictment. One meagre count alleges false statements to Congress; the other alleges obstruction of a congressional proceeding arising from the same testimony. (Notably, the grand jurors refused to approve a third count, which reportedly pertained to another allegedly false statement.) Both charges stem from Comey’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 30, 2020—specifically, the indictment cites an exchange Comey had with the Republican senator Ted Cruz about whether Comey had authorized leaks to the media about the F.B.I.’s 2016 investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Cruz referenced a 2017 hearing, during which the Republican senator Chuck Grassley asked Comey whether he had “ever been an anonymous source” or “authorized someone else at the F.B.I. to be an anonymous source” in news reports about matters concerning the Trump or Clinton investigations. When Comey denied both, Cruz pressed him about a contrary account provided by his former deputy director, Andrew McCabe.</p><blockquote class="BlockquoteEmbedWrapper-sc-MKszq djHmAg paywall blockquote-embed" data-testid="blockquote-wrapper"><div class="BlockquoteEmbedContent-edvnUB gRdfuS blockquote-embed__content"><p><em class="small">CRUZ</em>: “Now, what Mr. McCabe is saying and what you testified to this committee cannot both be true. One or the other is false. Who’s telling the truth?”</p></div></blockquote><blockquote class="BlockquoteEmbedWrapper-sc-MKszq djHmAg paywall blockquote-embed" data-testid="blockquote-wrapper"><div class="BlockquoteEmbedContent-edvnUB gRdfuS blockquote-embed__content"><p><em class="small">COMEY</em>: “I can only speak to my testimony. I stand by the testimony you summarized that I gave in May of 2017.”</p></div></blockquote><p class="paywall">The indictment alleges that “that statement was false,” because, as Comey “then and there knew, he in fact had authorized PERSON 3 to serve as an anonymous source in news reports regarding an F.B.I. investigation concerning PERSON 1.” This was presumably Hillary Clinton, because the leak at issue related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into Clinton’s e-mails and the Clinton Foundation.</p><div></div><div></div><p class="paywall">That’s it? That’s the crime? It’s hard to imagine that any responsible or ethical prosecutor would bring this case. In order for a false statement to be criminal, it must be made “knowingly and willfully.” Obstruction of Congress requires the defendant to have acted “corruptly.” The evidence that Comey did either appears sorely lacking. According to a 2018 report by the Justice Department’s inspector general, McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to speak with the reporter Devlin Barrett, who was with the <em>Wall Street Journal</em> at the time, about the F.B.I. investigation of the Clinton Foundation in October, 2016. But Comey did not join in that authorization, the inspector general found. Indeed, according to the inspector general, the evidence suggested that, after the article was published, McCabe misled Comey about McCabe’s role in the leak. While the two men remembered their conversation differently, the inspector general found that “the overwhelming weight of that evidence supported Comey’s version of the conversation.” (McCabe disputed the inspector general’s conclusions.)</p><div class="Container-VgtPr ekoLDG"></div><p class="paywall">In other words, there’s no evidence that Comey pre-approved the leak of information; the evidence that he blessed such action after the fact is contested at best. Who is Halligan’s chief witness going to be? McCabe, a man whom Trump repeatedly attacked for being biased against him? Among other inconvenient facts, the Justice Department unsuccessfully set out during Trump’s first term to prosecute McCabe over his alleged misstatements to investigators. As Benjamin Wittes and Anna Bower <a class="external-link" data-event-click='{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.lawfaremedia.org/article/the-situation--choose-your-own-adventure--lindsey-halligan-edition"}' data-offer-url="https://www.lawfaremedia.org/article/the-situation--choose-your-own-adventure--lindsey-halligan-edition" href="https://www.lawfaremedia.org/article/the-situation--choose-your-own-adventure--lindsey-halligan-edition" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">wrote</a> for Lawfare before the Comey indictment was issued, “It would be quite rich, having sought and failed to charge one party to a memory dispute to turn around and try to charge the other.” (It’s unlikely but conceivable that the indictment references a different episode: Comey’s use of the Columbia Law School professor Daniel Richman to funnel information to the New York <em>Times</em> about Trump’s demands, in 2017, that Comey pledge loyalty to him. Prosecutors reportedly interviewed Richman recently, but Richman’s role did not come up during Comey’s Senate testimony.)</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-beYvyV bRelOV grid--item"></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cFSKbf fubVbh grid grid-margins grid-items-0 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hkPQhP kHJhWe"><div class="GridItem-beYvyV bRelOV grid--item"><div class="BodyWrapper-kzyFNv BAJMj body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">“My heart is broken for the Department of Justice,” Comey said, in a video posted on Instagram, even as he expressed confidence about the ultimate outcome. One move would be for Comey’s lawyers to try to have the charges thrown out on the grounds of vindictive or selective prosecution, basically arguing that Comey was targeted for impermissible reasons. As it happens, Trump’s criminal lawyers—including the Deputy Attorney General, Todd Blanche—tried this very tactic against the former special counsel Jack Smith, seeking to have charges against Trump dismissed on the basis that President Joe Biden’s “publicly stated objective is to use the criminal justice system to incapacitate President Trump, his main political rival and the leading candidate in the upcoming election.” Their main evidence was a <em>Times</em> <a class="external-link" data-event-click='{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/04/02/us/politics/merrick-garland-biden-trump.html"}' data-offer-url="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/04/02/us/politics/merrick-garland-biden-trump.html" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/04/02/us/politics/merrick-garland-biden-trump.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">report</a> detailing Biden’s frustration with the slow pace of the Trump investigation. The U.S. district judge Tanya Chutkan appropriately rejected this long-shot bid, noting that courts are “properly hesitant to examine” prosecutorial motives and that there was “no indication that President Biden ever expressed any such comments to the Attorney General or the Justice Department, much less that such comments actually resulted in politically motivated action.” The strong aroma of abusive conduct in the Comey case might incline the judge, Michael Nachmanoff, to adopt a more skeptical approach to the charges. (Nachmanoff is a former public defender nominated by Biden. Trump, surprising no one, assailed him in a Truth Social post Friday morning as “a Crooked Joe Biden appointed Judge.”)</p><p class="paywall">Comey, in his Instagram video, expressed his eagerness to proceed. “Let’s have a trial,” he said. If it comes to that, the indictment’s seeming flimsiness suggests a conviction may be difficult to secure. That offers cold comfort. The danger in Trump’s second term was always that he would deploy the criminal law to punish his enemies. Now that moment has arrived. “Fear is the tool of a tyrant,” Comey said, quoting his daughter Maurene, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was fired in July, apparently solely because her last name is Comey. But tyrants work through enablers, too, and Trump has them in force. It is bone-chilling to see officials sworn to administer justice bend to Trump’s will, in violation of their ethical duties. In January, at Bondi’s confirmation hearing, the Democratic senator Amy Klobuchar sought assurances that Trump would not be permitted to tamper with criminal cases. “I believe that the Justice Department must be independent and must act independently,” Bondi assured her. “Politics will not play a part.” In the moment, her words offered a filament of hope. Today, they stand as an indictment—this one, sadly justified—of what the institution has become. ♦</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-beYvyV bRelOV grid--item"></div></div></div><div Comey | The New Yorker","tenant":"the-new-yorker","head.social.title":"The Flimsy, Dangerous Indictment of James Comey","head.social.description":"The charges against the former F.B.I. director look weak. But they may be just the start of Donald Trump’s long-threatened drive to use the Justice Department to go after his enemies.","head.promo.dek":"The charges against the former F.B.I. director look weak. But they may be just the start of Donald Trump’s long-threatened drive to use the Justice Department to go after his enemies.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"The next day, Trump addressed a post on his Truth Social platform to Attorney General Pam Bondi: “JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!” Prosecutors in Halligan’s office reportedly submitted a memorandum to Halligan outlining the weakness of the Comey case. None of those concerns mattered, apparently. Trump finally secured the indictment he had long been calling for. At this point, a prudent President would have stayed silent. Not this one. He posted, “JUSTICE IN AMERICA! One of the worst human beings this Country has ever been exposed to is James Comey, the former Corrupt Head of the FBI. . . . He has been so bad for our Country, for so long, and is now at the beginning of being held responsible for his crimes against our Nation.” The Department of Justice’s own news release contained the usual boilerplate about an indictment being merely an allegation and the presumption of innocence that all defendants enjoy—legal niceties that struck a particularly disingenuous note in light of Trump’s triumphalism. The President went on to suggest that more of his enemies may face charges: “It’s not a list, but I think there will be others,” he said on Friday morning, en route to watch the Ryder Cup.\nGrand-jury proceedings are well known to favor the prosecutor—a state-court judge famously remarked that “any good prosecutor can get a grand jury to indict a ham sandwich”—but there is not much meat in the Comey indictment. One meagre count alleges false statements to Congress; the other alleges obstruction of a congressional proceeding arising from the same testimony. (Notably, the grand jurors refused to approve a third count, which reportedly pertained to another allegedly false statement.) Both charges stem from Comey’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 30, 2020—specifically, the indictment cites an exchange Comey had with the Republican senator Ted Cruz about whether Comey had authorized leaks to the media about the F.B.I.’s 2016 investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Cruz referenced a 2017 hearing, during which the Republican senator Chuck Grassley asked Comey whether he had “ever been an anonymous source” or “authorized someone else at the F.B.I. to be an anonymous source” in news reports about matters concerning the Trump or Clinton investigations. When Comey denied both, Cruz pressed him about a contrary account provided by his former deputy director, Andrew McCabe.\n\nCRUZ: “Now, what Mr. McCabe is saying and what you testified to this committee cannot both be true. One or the other is false. Who’s telling the truth?”\n\n\nCOMEY: “I can only speak to my testimony. I stand by the testimony you summarized that I gave in May of 2017.”\n\nThe indictment alleges that “that statement was false,” because, as Comey “then and there knew, he in fact had authorized PERSON 3 to serve as an anonymous source in news reports regarding an F.B.I. investigation concerning PERSON 1.” This was presumably Hillary Clinton, because the leak at issue related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into Clinton’s e-mails and the Clinton Foundation.\nThat’s it? That’s the crime? It’s hard to imagine that any responsible or ethical prosecutor would bring this case. In order for a false statement to be criminal, it must be made “knowingly and willfully.” Obstruction of Congress requires the defendant to have acted “corruptly.” The evidence that Comey did either appears sorely lacking. According to a 2018 report by the Justice Department’s inspector general, McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to speak with the reporter Devlin Barrett, who was with the Wall Street Journal at the time, about the F.B.I. investigation of the Clinton Foundation in October, 2016. But Comey did not join in that authorization, the inspector general found. Indeed, according to the inspector general, the evidence suggested that, after the article was published, McCabe misled Comey about McCabe’s role in the leak. While the two men remembered their conversation differently, the inspector general found that “the overwhelming weight of that evidence supported Comey’s version of the conversation.” (McCabe disputed the inspector general’s conclusions.)\nIn other words, there’s no evidence that Comey pre-approved the leak of information; the evidence that he blessed such action after the fact is contested at best. Who is Halligan’s chief witness going to be? McCabe, a man whom Trump repeatedly attacked for being biased against him? Among other inconvenient facts, the Justice Department unsuccessfully set out during Trump’s first term to prosecute McCabe over his alleged misstatements to investigators. As Benjamin Wittes and Anna Bower wrote for Lawfare before the Comey indictment was issued, “It would be quite rich, having sought and failed to charge one party to a memory dispute to turn around and try to charge the other.” (It’s unlikely but conceivable that the indictment references a different episode: Comey’s use of the Columbia Law School professor Daniel Richman to funnel information to the New York Times about Trump’s demands, in 2017, that Comey pledge loyalty to him. Prosecutors reportedly interviewed Richman recently, but Richman’s role did not come up during Comey’s Senate testimony.)\n“My heart is broken for the Department of Justice,” Comey said, in a video posted on Instagram, even as he expressed confidence about the ultimate outcome. One move would be for Comey’s lawyers to try to have the charges thrown out on the grounds of vindictive or selective prosecution, basically arguing that Comey was targeted for impermissible reasons. As it happens, Trump’s criminal lawyers—including the Deputy Attorney General, Todd Blanche—tried this very tactic against the former special counsel Jack Smith, seeking to have charges against Trump dismissed on the basis that President Joe Biden’s “publicly stated objective is to use the criminal justice system to incapacitate President Trump, his main political rival and the leading candidate in the upcoming election.” Their main evidence was a Times report detailing Biden’s frustration with the slow pace of the Trump investigation. The U.S. district judge Tanya Chutkan appropriately rejected this long-shot bid, noting that courts are “properly hesitant to examine” prosecutorial motives and that there was “no indication that President Biden ever expressed any such comments to the Attorney General or the Justice Department, much less that such comments actually resulted in politically motivated action.” The strong aroma of abusive conduct in the Comey case might incline the judge, Michael Nachmanoff, to adopt a more skeptical approach to the charges. (Nachmanoff is a former public defender nominated by Biden. Trump, surprising no one, assailed him in a Truth Social post Friday morning as “a Crooked Joe Biden appointed Judge.”)\nComey, in his Instagram video, expressed his eagerness to proceed. “Let’s have a trial,” he said. If it comes to that, the indictment’s seeming flimsiness suggests a conviction may be difficult to secure. That offers cold comfort. The danger in Trump’s second term was always that he would deploy the criminal law to punish his enemies. Now that moment has arrived. “Fear is the tool of a tyrant,” Comey said, quoting his daughter Maurene, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was fired in July, apparently solely because her last name is Comey. But tyrants work through enablers, too, and Trump has them in force. It is bone-chilling to see officials sworn to administer justice bend to Trump’s will, in violation of their ethical duties. In January, at Bondi’s confirmation hearing, the Democratic senator Amy Klobuchar sought assurances that Trump would not be permitted to tamper with criminal cases. “I believe that the Justice Department must be independent and must act independently,” Bondi assured her. “Politics will not play a part.” In the moment, her words offered a filament of hope. Today, they stand as an indictment—this one, sadly justified—of what the institution has become. ♦","isBasedOn":"","articleSection":"the lede","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Ruth She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. She is a former writer for “Saturday Night Live” and “Rugrats.” Her books include the novels “[Him Her Him Again the End of Him](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0743296249\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Starting from Happy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1439101299\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” both of which were finalists for the Thurber Prize; numerous children’s books, among them “[Now Everybody Really Hates Me](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0064434400\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=2&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Meet My Staff](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0060274840\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=3&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[Tired Town](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FTired-Town-Patricia-Marx\u002Fdp\u002F1250859123\u002F)”; and nonfiction books, including “[Let’s Be Less Stupid: An Attempt to Maintain My Mental Faculties](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1455554960\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=4&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Why Don’t You Write My Eulogy Now So I Can Correct It?: A Mother’s Suggestions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1250301963\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=5&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[You Can Only Yell at Me for One Thing at a Time: Rules for Couples](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FYou-Only-Yell-Thing-Time\u002Fdp\u002F1250225132),” illustrated by Roz Chast.\n\nMarx was the first woman elected to the *Harvard Lampoon*. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fjames-comeys-intellectual-history","isExternal":false},"James Comey"]," bore a single, telling signature: that of Lindsey Halligan, installed by President ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Ftag\u002Fdonald-trump","isExternal":false},"Donald Trump"]," just three days earlier to serve as the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. Halligan is an insurance lawyer turned Trump attorney and White House aide; in March, Trump appointed her to remove “improper ideology” from the Smithsonian. She has scant experience in federal courts and none as a prosecutor. Her predecessor in the position, a seasoned prosecutor nominated by Trump, was ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fthe-lede\u002Fdonald-trumps-firing-of-a-federal-prosecutor-crosses-the-reddest-of-lines","isExternal":false},"forced out"]," last Friday, according to numerous news reports, after balking at demands to concoct cases against Comey, in addition to New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, and others."]],["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"inset-right","attrs":{},"childTypes":["callout:sidebar"]},"ref":"","type":"callout:inset-right"},["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"sidebar","attrs":{},"childTypes":[]},"ref":"","type":"callout:sidebar"},["p",{"class":"paywall"},["strong","The Lede"],["br"],["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fthe-lede","isExternal":false},["em","Reporting and commentary on what you need to know today."]]]]],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The next day, Trump addressed a post on his Truth Social platform to Attorney General Pam Bondi: “JUSTICE MUST BE SERVED, NOW!!!” Prosecutors in Halligan’s office ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fabcnews.go.com\u002FPolitics\u002Fnewly-appointed-us-attorney-attempt-charge-james-comey\u002Fstory?id=125906268","rel":"nofollow noopener","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fabcnews.go.com\u002FPolitics\u002Fnewly-appointed-us-attorney-attempt-charge-james-comey\u002Fstory?id=125906268"},"isExternal":true},"reportedly"]," submitted a memorandum to Halligan outlining the weakness of the Comey case. None of those concerns mattered, apparently. Trump finally secured the indictment he had long been calling for. At this point, a prudent President would have stayed silent. Not this one. He posted, “JUSTICE IN AMERICA! One of the worst human beings this Country has ever been exposed to is James Comey, the former Corrupt Head of the FBI. . . . He has been so bad for our Country, for so long, and is now at the beginning of being held responsible for his crimes against our Nation.” The Department of Justice’s own news release contained the usual boilerplate about an indictment being merely an allegation and the presumption of innocence that all defendants enjoy—legal niceties that struck a particularly disingenuous note in light of Trump’s triumphalism. The President went on to suggest that more of his enemies may face charges: “It’s not a list, but I think there will be others,” he said on Friday morning, en route to watch the Ryder Cup."],["cm-unit"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Grand-jury proceedings are well known to favor the prosecutor—a state-court judge famously remarked that “any good prosecutor can get a grand jury to indict a ham sandwich”—but there is not much meat in the Comey indictment. One meagre count alleges false statements to Congress; the other alleges obstruction of a congressional proceeding arising from the same testimony. (Notably, the grand jurors refused to approve a third count, which reportedly pertained to another allegedly false statement.) Both charges stem from Comey’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 30, 2020—specifically, the indictment cites an exchange Comey had with the Republican senator Ted Cruz about whether Comey had authorized leaks to the media about the F.B.I.’s 2016 investigations involving Trump and Hillary Clinton. Cruz referenced a 2017 hearing, during which the Republican senator Chuck Grassley asked Comey whether he had “ever been an anonymous source” or “authorized someone else at the F.B.I. to be an anonymous source” in news reports about matters concerning the Trump or Clinton investigations. When Comey denied both, Cruz pressed him about a contrary account provided by his former deputy director, Andrew McCabe."],["blockquote",{"class":"paywall"},["p",["em",{"class":"small"},"CRUZ"],": “Now, what Mr. McCabe is saying and what you testified to this committee cannot both be true. One or the other is false. Who’s telling the truth?”"]],["blockquote",{"class":"paywall"},["p",["em",{"class":"small"},"COMEY"],": “I can only speak to my testimony. I stand by the testimony you summarized that I gave in May of 2017.”"]],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The indictment alleges that “that statement was false,” because, as Comey “then and there knew, he in fact had authorized PERSON 3 to serve as an anonymous source in news reports regarding an F.B.I. investigation concerning PERSON 1.” This was presumably Hillary Clinton, because the leak at issue related to the F.B.I.’s investigation into Clinton’s e-mails and the Clinton Foundation."],["journey-inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["inline-newsletter",{"newsletterType":"slim-newsletter","newsletters":[]}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"That’s it? That’s the crime? It’s hard to imagine that any responsible or ethical prosecutor would bring this case. In order for a false statement to be criminal, it must be made “knowingly and willfully.” Obstruction of Congress requires the defendant to have acted “corruptly.” The evidence that Comey did either appears sorely lacking. According to a 2018 report by the Justice Department’s inspector general, McCabe authorized F.B.I. officials to speak with the reporter Devlin Barrett, who was with the ",["em","Wall Street Journal"]," at the time, about the F.B.I. investigation of the Clinton Foundation in October, 2016. But Comey did not join in that authorization, the inspector general found. Indeed, according to the inspector general, the evidence suggested that, after the article was published, McCabe misled Comey about McCabe’s role in the leak. While the two men remembered their conversation differently, the inspector general found that “the overwhelming weight of that evidence supported Comey’s version of the conversation.” (McCabe disputed the inspector general’s conclusions.)"],["inline-embed",{"type":"cneinterlude","props":{"brand":"newyorker","embeddedVideos":[],"hasExcludedEmbed":false,"playerBase":"https:\u002F\u002Fplayer.cnevids.com","isRightRail":false,"relatedVideo":{"showRelatedVideo":false,"brand":"newyorker","related":null,"pageSize":12}}}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"In other words, there’s no evidence that Comey pre-approved the leak of information; the evidence that he blessed such action after the fact is contested at best. Who is Halligan’s chief witness going to be? McCabe, a man whom Trump repeatedly attacked for being biased against him? Among other inconvenient facts, the Justice Department unsuccessfully set out during Trump’s first term to prosecute McCabe over his alleged misstatements to investigators. As Benjamin Wittes and Anna Bower ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.lawfaremedia.org\u002Farticle\u002Fthe-situation--choose-your-own-adventure--lindsey-halligan-edition","rel":"nofollow noopener","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.lawfaremedia.org\u002Farticle\u002Fthe-situation--choose-your-own-adventure--lindsey-halligan-edition"},"isExternal":true},"wrote"]," for Lawfare before the Comey indictment was issued, “It would be quite rich, having sought and failed to charge one party to a memory dispute to turn around and try to charge the other.” (It’s unlikely but conceivable that the indictment references a different episode: Comey’s use of the Columbia Law School professor Daniel Richman to funnel information to the New York ",["em","Times"]," about Trump’s demands, in 2017, that Comey pledge loyalty to him. Prosecutors reportedly interviewed Richman recently, but Richman’s role did not come up during Comey’s Senate testimony.)"],["ad",{"position":"mid-content"}],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"“My heart is broken for the Department of Justice,” Comey said, in a video posted on Instagram, even as he expressed confidence about the ultimate outcome. One move would be for Comey’s lawyers to try to have the charges thrown out on the grounds of vindictive or selective prosecution, basically arguing that Comey was targeted for impermissible reasons. As it happens, Trump’s criminal lawyers—including the Deputy Attorney General, Todd Blanche—tried this very tactic against the former special counsel Jack Smith, seeking to have charges against Trump dismissed on the basis that President Joe Biden’s “publicly stated objective is to use the criminal justice system to incapacitate President Trump, his main political rival and the leading candidate in the upcoming election.” Their main evidence was a ",["em","Times"]," ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F02\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fmerrick-garland-biden-trump.html","rel":"nofollow noopener","attributes":{"data-offer-url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F02\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fmerrick-garland-biden-trump.html"},"isExternal":true},"report"]," detailing Biden’s frustration with the slow pace of the Trump investigation. The U.S. district judge Tanya Chutkan appropriately rejected this long-shot bid, noting that courts are “properly hesitant to examine” prosecutorial motives and that there was “no indication that President Biden ever expressed any such comments to the Attorney General or the Justice Department, much less that such comments actually resulted in politically motivated action.” The strong aroma of abusive conduct in the Comey case might incline the judge, Michael Nachmanoff, to adopt a more skeptical approach to the charges. (Nachmanoff is a former public defender nominated by Biden. Trump, surprising no one, assailed him in a Truth Social post Friday morning as “a Crooked Joe Biden appointed Judge.”)"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Comey, in his Instagram video, expressed his eagerness to proceed. “Let’s have a trial,” he said. If it comes to that, the indictment’s seeming flimsiness suggests a conviction may be difficult to secure. That offers cold comfort. The danger in Trump’s second term was always that he would deploy the criminal law to punish his enemies. Now that moment has arrived. “Fear is the tool of a tyrant,” Comey said, quoting his daughter Maurene, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who was fired in July, apparently solely because her last name is Comey. But tyrants work through enablers, too, and Trump has them in force. It is bone-chilling to see officials sworn to administer justice bend to Trump’s will, in violation of their ethical duties. In January, at Bondi’s confirmation hearing, the Democratic senator Amy Klobuchar sought assurances that Trump would not be permitted to tamper with criminal cases. “I believe that the Justice Department must be independent and must act independently,” Bondi assured her. “Politics will not play a part.” In the moment, her words offered a filament of hope. Today, they stand as an indictment—this one, sadly justified—of what the institution has become. ♦"]],"pageStructure":[["inline-embed",123,"callout"],["inline-embed",24,"callout"],["p",202],["cm-unit",0],["p",186],["blockquote",58],["blockquote",46],["p",60],["p",166],["inline-embed",0,"cneinterlude"],["p",171],["ad",0],["p",250],["p",195]],"hasAffiliateLinks":false,"affiliateLinksCount":0,"isCommerceContent":false,"contributorSpotLightProps":{"header":{"name":"Ruth Marcus","title":"Ruth Marcus, a former columnist for the Washington Post, became a contributing writer at The New Yorker in June, 2025.
